So, historically, what have been the links between crime rates and, you know, the economy, broadly speaking?
The links appear to be very direct, especially when we're talking about the kinds of crimes we are in today, property crimes.
In every recession, back several decades, during the recession, property-crime rates have increased, and also, I should say, violent-crime rates very often as well.
So, if we look back to 2001, 2002, that recession, crime rates went up.
When we look back to the early '90s or the early '80s recessions, crime rates went up.
Mid-'70s, crime rates went up; late '50s, crime rates went up.
We can go all the way back to the Great Depression, and then we reach an interesting, I think, paradox, but almost an exception that proves the rule.
We did not see substantial crime increases nationwide during the 1930s, and one reason for that seems to be the countercyclical stimulus programs put into place by the Roosevelt administration.

The Works Progress Administration, the so-called WPA, the Civilian Conservation Corps, put hundreds of thousands into the millions of people back to work, and that seemed to mute crime increases, and that has obvious implications for the incoming Obama administration's proposed stimulus package.
